function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The generated code currently stores users and chats in memory, which means that all data will be lost if the server is restarted. A better approach would be to use a database to persist this data. This would allow the data to survive server restarts and also make it easier to handle multiple simultaneous requests.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation of the login function does not handle the case where the user does not exist in the system. It would be better to add a check for this and return an appropriate error message if the user does not exist. This would make the system more user-friendly and also more secure, as it would not reveal whether a given email address is registered in the system or not.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation does not include any form of password security. The passwords are stored in plain text, which is a significant security risk. It would be better to store hashed versions of the passwords, and compare these hashes when a user tries to log in. This would ensure that even if the user data is compromised, the passwords would remain secure.
